anchor.surface_text: These findings are obviously res-judicata and if the plaintiffs learned counsel had not conceded the point the question would at once have been raised and the previous judgments, which were exhibited Exhibits DD and DF would-have concluded the matter. But as the point was conceded in all three Courts it was not necessary for the defendants to fall back on the previous decisions.

concepts.interpretation: Findings in prior suits instituted by Mst. Biro declaring the property as non-ancestral bind the parties and prevent reopening the issue.

anchor.surface_text: Before us, the plaintiffs learned counsel tried to reopen the concurrent finding of the three Courts about the not- ancestral nature of the property but we did not allow him to do so. The question is a mixed question of law and fact and the admission involved both.

concepts.unlisted_label: Mixed Question of Law and Fact
concepts.unlisted_description: Issue conceded in lower courts involving inseparably entwined facts and law cannot be reopened in higher court without disentangling.

anchor.surface_text: Paragraph 23 2  of Rattigans Digest of Customary Law says that- In regard to the acquired property of her father, the daughter is preferred to the collaterals. That is not disputed but what the plaintiffs contend is that she only succeeds as a limited heir

concepts.unlisted_label: Daughter Preferred to Collaterals in Acquired Property
concepts.unlisted_description: Under Punjab customary law (Rattigan para 23(2)), daughter succeeds in preference to collaterals to father's acquired property.

anchor.surface_text: Rattigan quotes the following passage from page 61 of Roe and Rattigans Tribal -Law-of the Punjab at page 411 of the 13th edition of his Digest Where a succession of a married daughter is allowed, the general principle is that she succeeds not as an ordinary heir,, but merely as the means of passing on the property to another male, whose descent from her father in the female line is allowed under exceptional circumstances to count as if it were descent in the male line.

concepts.interpretation: Applies to non-ancestral property; daughter has no more power than a widow.

concepts.unlisted_label: Limited Estate of Married Daughter (Agricultural Jats Custom)
concepts.unlisted_description: Daughter holds for life like a widow; estate passes to her sons and male issue or reverts to father's agnates on failure.

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel for the plaintiffs relies on, paragraph 64 of Rattigans Digest where it is stated that except in two cases which do -not apply here, no female in possession of property from, among others, her father can permanently alienate it.

concepts.unlisted_label: No Permanent Alienation by Female Heir
concepts.unlisted_description: Under Punjab custom (Rattigan para 64), female successor from father cannot permanently alienate except in specified cases.

holdings.text: The concurrent finding of the three courts on the non-ancestral nature of the property cannot be reopened as it involves a mixed question of law and fact conceded below and is res judicata from prior suits.

anchor.surface_text: Before us, the plaintiffs learned counsel tried to reopen the concurrent finding of the three Courts about the not- ancestral nature of the property but we did not allow him to do so. The question is a mixed question of law and fact and the admission involved both. We were not shown how the facts admitted could be disentangled from the law so that we could determine whether the conclusion of law drawn from the admitted facts was wrong. The learned trial Judge said that the admission was made because of a previous decision in a former suit between the same parties or their predecessors.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plaintiffs conceded in all lower courts; mixed law-fact issue cannot be disentangled; prior suits (Exhibits DD, DF) establish res judicata.

holdings.text: The whole of the land in dispute must be accepted as non-ancestral.

anchor.surface_text: It, must therefore be accepted here that the whole of the land in dispute was non-ancestral. That brings us to the question of heirship. Paragraph 23 2  of Rattigans Digest of Customary Law says that- In regard to the acquired property of her father, the daughter is preferred to the collaterals.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows from concession, inability to reopen, and res judicata.

holdings.text: Under Punjab custom for agricultural Jats, in non-ancestral property, a married daughter succeeds as a limited heir merely to pass the property to her sons and male issue, who exclude father's collaterals.

anchor.surface_text: Paragraph 23 2  of Rattigans Digest of Customary Law says that- In regard to the acquired property of her father, the daughter is preferred to the collaterals. That is not disputed but what the plaintiffs contend is that she only succeeds as a limited heir ... We were not shown any decision which has taken a contrary view.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies Rattigan para 23(2) and quote from Tribal Law of Punjab; supported by precedents Lehna v. Mst. Thakri and Lal Singh v. Roor Singh.

holdings.text: Rattigan paragraph 64 prohibiting permanent alienation by female heir from father does not apply, as the issue is acceleration of estate, not validity of alienation after death.

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel for the plaintiffs relies on, paragraph 64 of Rattigans Digest where it is stated that except in two cases which do -not apply here, no female in possession of property from, among others, her father can permanently alienate it. But we are not concerned with an alienation here. The gift to the sons may or may not be good after Mst. Biros death as a gift. The question is whether there was an acceleration.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes alienation validity from acceleration/surrender doctrine.

holdings.text: Retention by Mst. Biro of a tiny house does not prevent acceleration of the estate via surrender, as omission of small portion due to oversight does not invalidate bona fide surrender.

anchor.surface_text: We turn, next, to the question of surrender and the. only question there is whether the retention by Mst. Biro of the house would prevent an acceleration of the estate, The extent of the property covered by the gift is over 253 bighas. ... The law about this has been correctly set out in Mullas Hindu Law, 11th edition, page 217 ... The present case is, in our opinion, covered by that rule.

holdings.reasoning_summary: House is insignificant (few rooms, sons live there); applies Mulla's Hindu Law rule on bona fide surrender omitting small portion.

holdings.text: The gift operated to accelerate the succession to the daughter`s sons; plaintiffs are no longer reversioners even if otherwise entitled on failure of daughter`s line.

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the High Court that the gift operated accelerate the succession. That being the case, the plaintiffs are no longer the reversions even if they would otherwise have been entitled to succeed on failure of the daughters sons and their line

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows from valid surrender/acceleration excluding reversioners; agrees with High Court.
